section-block.rac_essential-question: How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Paul DuBois Jacobs and Jennifer Swender, and illustrated by Huy Voun Lee
section-block.rac_book_summary: This story is about a classroom of children who practice a fire drill. They listen to their teacher and walk carefully. They stay safe and sound!

section-block.rac_body-text: Sing Grand Ole Duke of York with children. Model standing up and pointing up as you say “up” and sitting down and pointing down as you say “down.”
Review spatial sense by asking children to recall the song. What words did we use to describe where something was? (up, down, in, out, etc.)

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Fire Drill by Paul DuBois Jacobs and Jennifer Swender, and illustrated by Huy Voun Lee.
You know Lala loves all sorts of books, and she loves to look for location words in story books like this one!
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. What happens during a fire drill?

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Spatial Sense: Pause and ask children to describe where objects and people are in relation to each other.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This book is called Fire Drill. Does anybody know what a fire drill is? What do you think will happen in the story?
Fire drills help us practice getting to a safe place quickly.
I see a poster on the wall. It has rules for the fire drill on it. The poster says to follow directions, or do what the teacher says. Why do you think you need to do that?
The children are not all together. Where are the different children? What are they near? What are they on? What are their hands in?
Why do you think loud bells ring? Do things sound louder when they are near or far?
Where is the sign with the fire drill rules? These are the first three rules again. How are the children following the rules so far? (MB)
A thrill is something exciting or fun. How do the children act when they are back and safe? Are they having fun?
Let’s talk about the guiding question: What happens during a fire drill?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk to discuss the guiding question. Then use Equity Sticks to pick several children to share.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: They get to a safe spot quickly.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about fire drills as children watch.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Where do the children wait during a fire drill?
Why is it important to listen to teachers during a fire drill?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children develop an understanding of spatial sense by using positional words and phrases, such as “beside,” “up,” and “down.” Practicing with these words develops spatial awareness. Connect the positional words in the book to real life examples by using the same phrases throughout the day.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Healthy me | WEEK 4: Safe and Sound

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Move Carefully Through Surroundings
section-block.rac_body-text: Explain to children that their surroundings are the things and people all around them. Talk about how moving carefully can be important to not hurt yourself or the people around you. Help children come up with examples of when you might be more careful, like if something is hot or easy to break, and model careful movements.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will revisit some pages of Fire Drill by Paul DuBois Jacobs and Jennifer Swender, and illustrated by Huy Voun Lee. We will notice how the children move carefully.
As a big dog, Clifford moves carefully and pays attention. He loves practicing fire drills and reading books about them like this one!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Spatial Sense: Point out location words as they appear in the book and your discussions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: We’ll use our Mind Builder of moving carefully to learn more about how to be careful with our bodies during a fire drill.
It says “be quiet, listen to the teacher.” Why is it important to hear what the teacher is saying?
The children are in a line beside each other. Why do the children need to be careful of each other’s bodies when they are beside each other? (MB)
Why is it important not to run or talk during a fire drill? (MB)
The book says “do not climb, do not chase.” Why are these rules important? (MB)
Why is it important to wait until the teacher says “okay”? How can listening carefully be an important part of being careful with your body? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Encourage children to practice controlling their bodies and being respectful of other children’s space during a fire drill.
Have children follow the steps for a fire drill within the room and narrate them. Encourage them to move carefully, and to define where they are in relation to other children or class objects.
Once children are lined up, ask for volunteers to share who they are next to and how they will be careful when moving near their classmates.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about moving carefully during a fire drill.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Boundaries are an important part of emotional development. It starts with children being aware of where their bodies are in relation to other children. Children can then relate how they feel about their personal space to how others feel about their personal space, and why boundaries are important. (Epstein 2007, pp. 100-103)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Healthy me | WEEK 4: Safe and Sound

section-block.rac_body-text: Share that a graph is used to organize information. Remind children of previously made graphs and share how creating a graph helps us understand information.
Give each child a sticky note and a crayon. Ask them to draw a circle, square, or triangle, and hand it back. Have children help you graph the sticky notes on a pre-made grid.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Fire Drill by Paul DuBois Jacobs and Jennifer Swender, and illustrated by Huy Voun Lee.
Lala loves reading stories about staying safe!
It is important to be safe during a fire drill. As we read today, think about this guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How do we keep track of all the children during a fire drill?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do the children do? What do the adults do? Let’s count adults.
Let’s use red Connecting Cubes to help us count. We’ll use one red cube to stand for each adult.
What does this adult do when the fire drill starts? What do the children do?
The children line up quickly and quietly. Let’s count the children we see.
Let’s use blue Connecting Cubes to help us count. We’ll use one blue cube to stand for each child.
The children are walking in pairs. Let’s arrange our cubes into pairs.
How does being part of a pair change how they move? How does it help with safety? (MB)
What does the teacher count? Why do you think the teacher counts the children? What do the children do?
Let’s make a graph using the red and blue Connecting Cubes we counted to find out if there are more adults or children in the class.
There are a lot more children! Why does that make it more important for the children to listen and be quiet?
Did you listen and remember as we read the story today?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How do we keep track of all the children during a fire drill?
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: We call out each child’s name.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you draw and write together about how to stay safe during a fire drill.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do you do with buddies during a fire drill?
Why is it important to keep track of everyone? What else can we do to stay safe?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Safety drills can be worrying for many children. Help children cope by providing context (fires rarely happen) and showing patterns of behavior (practicing fire drills). Role-playing situations, like fire drills, give children situational context and shows them what to expect. It can also help to explain the unlikeliness of a real emergency.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: healthy me | WEEK 4: Safe and Sound

section-block.rac_body-text: Discuss the importance of being careful with your body. Help children make a list of the things they can do to stay safe in the classroom.
Make a real-life pictograph with the children acting as the pictures! Choose an easily-visible attribute like short/long hair to create two types of data to compare.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Five Little Froggies Jumping on the Bed. It is a song about frogs who are not being safe.
Fire Drill and Five Little Froggies Jumping on the Bed both focus on being safe. Let’s look for connections between them aswe read.
How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Safe and Sound
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s sing the song together!
section.rac_body-text: Sing the song with the children and then review the pictures. Ask questions and use Equity Sticks to choose children to respond.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The frogs are jumping on the bed. Are they are being careful with their bodies when they jump? (MB)
What happened? What did Mama do? What did the doctor say? The doctor is telling Mama how to keep the little froggies safe!
Were the frogs being safe? Did they listen to what the doctor said? Why should you listen to what the doctor tells you?
Where are all of the frogs? What are they doing on the bed now? Are they being careful with their bodies? (MB)
What can the frogs do to protect themselves and their bodies?

section.rac_body-text: Make frog stick puppets using found objects like buttons for eyes and paper plates or lunch bags for the body. Provide green paint and coloring supplies, and encourage children to use their imaginations to make their own little froggies. Once children have completed their puppets (and they’ve dried properly), sing the song again with all of the children holding their froggies.
Provide a writing prompt about how to move safely and give feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children first learn about classification by sorting. Graphing allows for children to begin more complex classification. Simple bar graphs can help children interact with visual information, work together, and learn from each other.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: healthy me | WEEK 4: Safe and Sound

section-block.rac_body-text: Guide children to think about what they learned about safety. Help them make the connection between being safe and healthy habits like eating well and brushing teeth.
Sing and dance to the Hokey Pokey, but vary the location words by verse. In addition to in and out, use up and down. Ask children to supply other pairs of location words.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s retell and reenact the book Fire Drill by Paul DuBois Jacobs and Jennifer Swender, and illustrated by Huy Voun Lee.
Who remembers if this book tells us a story or teaches us information?
We read about how children should behave during a fire drill. When we read today, I want you to think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How do fire drills help us stay safe?

section.rac_body-text: Let’s reread the book one more time together. This time, we will act out the fire drill with the children in the story.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s follow each of the steps of the fire drill rules one at a time.
First let’s all be quiet. Shhh!
Now follow my directions. Everyone stand up carefully. (MB)
Let’s get in a line. When you are in line, check and remember who you are between.
Remember to move quickly, quietly, and carefully.
Now that we are all in a line, we are going to walk around the classroom. Look at what you are near.
Now we will stay in one place until an adult says to go back.
Time to go back! Stay quiet and move carefully until we are back.
Great job, everyone!
On the count of three, we will sound like bells for five seconds. Stop when I raise my hand.
The children each listen for their names, then raise a hand and say, “Here I am!” I want everyone to raise a hand. Let’s call out, “Here I am!”
The class in the story has a fire drill, but there are other types of drills too.
section.rac_body-text: Review your class’s procedures for other types of drills you practice, like earthquake, tornado, or sheltering in place.

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How do fire drills help us stay safe?
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: We learn what to do if there is a real fire.
They teach us how to move carefully.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write a story about a fire drill.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How should you walk during a fire?
During a fire you should walk c____ (carefully).
During a fire you should walk carefully.
What other safety drills do we practice?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Visual support and gestures can help multilingual learners become comfortable with location terms. Action songs like Hokey Pokey and pointing out real-world examples in context can help support their acquisition of words to foster spatial sense.
